Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the amount of corn used for ethanol production by stating that it is more than the amount used to feed livestock and poultry in the United States. The expert's verdict mentions that not all of the corn sent to ethanol plants ends up as fuel, as a portion is converted into ethanol feed.
Understate: The claim may be understating the amount of corn used to feed livestock and poultry in the United States by implying that it is less than the amount used for ethanol production. The expert's verdict mentions that 38.7 percent of the corn crop is projected to go towards "feed and residual use."
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support to conclusively prove that more corn is used for ethanol production than for feeding livestock and poultry. The expert's verdict mentions that the data from the U.S. Department of Agriculture estimates that 42 percent of the corn crop will go towards ethanol production, but it also highlights the complexities of calculating the actual amount of corn used for fuel.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the increase in corn used for ethanol production is solely due to the Renewable Fuel Standard. The expert's verdict mentions that renewable fuel standards have contributed to the rise in corn used for ethanol, but it also acknowledges that other factors may be at play.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the increase in corn used for ethanol production. The expert's verdict mentions that renewable fuel standards have driven the increase, but it does not explore other potential factors that may contribute to the shift in corn allocation.
Contradict fact: The claim does not appear to contradict any known facts, as the expert's verdict confirms that the percentage of corn used for ethanol has been on the rise.
